qas.question: Which branch of anthropology attempts to explain human economic behavior?
Economic anthropology covers what scope of human economic behavior?
What is economic anthropology highly critical of?
Who was the Polish-British founder of Anthropology?
What is Economic Anthropology mostly focused upon?
What type of anthropology attempts explain human finances?
What study focuses on the history of human economics rather than culural?
What alternative to gift-giving exchange did Mauss study?
What school of thought did Marx found?

context: <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>Economic<a0_0/> anthropology<b6_0/><b5_0/> attempts to explain human economic behavior in its widest <a1_0>historic, geographic and cultural<a1_0/> scope. It has a complex relationship with the <a2_0>discipline of economics<a2_0/>, of which it is highly critical. Its origins as a sub-field of anthropology begin with the Polish-British founder of Anthropology, <a3_0>Bronislaw Malinowski<a3_0/>, and his French compatriot, Marcel Mauss, on the nature of gift-giving exchange (or reciprocity) as an alternative to <b7_0>market exchange<b7_0/>. Economic Anthropology remains, for the most part, focused upon <a4_0>exchange<a4_0/>. The school of thought derived from Marx and known as <b8_0>Political Economy<b8_0/> focuses on production, in contrast. Economic Anthropologists have abandoned the primitivist niche they were relegated to by economists, and have now turned to examine corporations, banks, and the global financial system from an anthropological perspective.
